title: 106_s1305
content: The Act is titled the "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 1999." It includes reforms to the listing process, emphasizing the use of the best scientific and commercial data available. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 1999" includes amendments to definitions and general provisions, emphasizing the use of the best scientific and commercial data available. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 1999" amends the Endangered Species Act to require sufficient biological information to support recovery planning for endangered or threatened species. It also updates the petition process for species listing. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 1999" amends the Endangered Species Act to update the petition process for species listing by requiring specific documentation and information. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 1999" amends the Endangered Species Act by requiring specific documentation and information for species listing petitions, including distribution, methodology, status and trends of populations, threats, peer-reviewed data, and expert opinions. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 1999" requires the Secretary to notify State agencies and solicit their assessment on petitioned actions for species listing. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 1999" mandates the Secretary to inform State agencies and seek their assessment on potential listings of species as endangered or threatened. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 1999" requires the Secretary to consider assessments submitted before determining if a petition for listing a species is warranted. Additionally, the Act now mandates holding at least 2 public hearings in each State where a species is proposed for listing as endangered or threatened. The "Endangered Species Listing and Delisting Process Reform Act of 1999" mandates holding public hearings in affected rural areas with populations under 10,000 inhabitants for proposed regulations. The definition of a rural area is a county or unincorporated area without a city or town exceeding 10,000 inhabitants. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to remove certain definitions and make reforms to the listing process, including making listing data publicly available upon publication of proposed regulations. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to require the Secretary to make all information used for species determinations public, including scientific studies and data, with the exception of information not subject to the Freedom of Information Act or prohibited from disclosure. The Privacy Act under section 552a of title 5, United States Code requires the Secretary to establish criteria for scientific studies supporting the listing of endangered or threatened species. The Secretary must use field data for species determinations and may not rely solely on data from landowners. The Secretary must accept data from landowners on the status of a species observed on their land and include it in the record for determining if the species is endangered or threatened. SEC. 3. DEADLINE FOR DEVELOPMENT OF RECOVERY PLANS. Amends the Endangered Species Act to require the Secretary to begin developing a recovery plan for a species on the date of proposed regulation and issue a final plan by the date of final regulation. SEC. 4. DELISTING. Section 4(f) of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include provisions for the change in status of a species from endangered to threatened or vice versa upon meeting recovery plan criteria. The Secretary is required to publish a notice in the Federal Register for any change in status or removal from listing based on the fulfillment of recovery plan criteria. Upon meeting recovery plan criteria, the Secretary must publish a notice in the Federal Register for the removal of species from the list under subsection (c).
